sn21.3:1.2: At one time the Buddha was staying near Sāvatthī in Jeta’s Grove, Anāthapiṇḍika’s monastery.
sn21.3:1.3: At that time Venerables Sāriputta and Moggallāna were staying near Rājagaha, in the Bamboo Grove, the squirrels’ feeding ground.
sn21.3:1.4: Then in the late afternoon, Venerable Sāriputta came out of retreat, went to Venerable Moggallāna, and exchanged greetings with him.
sn21.3:1.5: When the greetings and polite conversation were over, Sāriputta sat down to one side, and said to Mahāmoggallāna:
sn21.3:2.1: “Reverend Moggallāna, your faculties are so very clear, and your complexion is pure and bright.
sn21.3:2.2: Have you spent the day in a peaceful meditation?”
sn21.3:2.3: “Reverend, I’ve spent the day in a coarse meditation.
sn21.3:2.4: But I have had some Dhamma talk.”
sn21.3:2.5: “Who did you have a Dhamma talk with?”
sn21.3:2.7: “But Reverend, the Buddha is far away. He’s staying near Sāvatthī in Jeta’s Grove, Anāthapiṇḍika’s monastery.
sn21.3:2.8: Did you go to him with your psychic power,
sn21.3:2.9: or did he come to you?”
sn21.3:2.10: “No reverend, I didn’t go to him with my psychic power,
sn21.3:2.11: nor did he come to me.
sn21.3:2.12: Rather, the Buddha cleared his clairvoyance and clairaudience towards me,
sn21.3:2.13: and I cleared my clairvoyance and clairaudience towards him.”
sn21.3:2.14: “But what manner of Dhamma talk did you have together?”
sn21.3:3.1: “Well, reverend, I said to the Buddha,
sn21.3:3.2: ‘Sir, they speak of one who is energetic.
sn21.3:3.3: How is an energetic person defined?’
sn21.3:3.4: When I said this, the Buddha said,
sn21.3:3.5: ‘Moggallāna, it’s when a mendicant lives with energy roused up:
sn21.3:3.6: “Gladly, let only skin, sinews, and bones remain! Let the flesh and blood waste away in my body! I will not stop trying until I have achieved what is possible by human strength, energy, and vigor.”
sn21.3:3.7: That’s how a person is energetic.’
sn21.3:3.8: That’s the Dhamma talk I had together with the Buddha.”
sn21.3:4.1: “Reverend, next to Venerable Mahāmoggallāna I’m like a few pieces of gravel next to the Himalayas, the king of mountains.
sn21.3:4.3: Venerable Mahāmoggallāna is so mighty and powerful he could, if he wished, live on for the proper lifespan.”
sn21.3:5.1: “Reverend, next to Venerable Sāriputta I’m like a few grains of salt next to a mound of salt.
sn21.3:5.3: Venerable Sāriputta has been commended, complimented, and praised by the Buddha:
sn21.3:6.3: any mendicant who has crossed over
sn21.3:7.1: And so these two spiritual giants agreed with each others’ fine words.
